document.text: would- rather die a thousand deaths. But there was a spirit of reuniting. After the hour-long meeting, Union artillerymen started a 100-gun salute in celebration, but Grant ordered it stopped. The terms bad been generous. Rebel soldiers had been allowed to keep their horses and mules and go home officers kept their side arms. The town has moved three miles away from its 1865 site since then, to gather around the railroad station, now an arts and crafts center. Across the street is Jeanne Stanleys restaurant, where are served charcoaled steaks, hospitality and cheerful tales about her last vacation to Thailand and Japan. On the edge of town a new furniture plant is paying passing good wages, along with the Appomattox Garment Co. and the gas pipeline pumping station. Appomattox is still a friendly little country village that can hardly be called industrialized, but on its own terms it has a newly industrial life. It has been, says Calvin Robinson, Appomattox histor ian and enthusiast,an induce ment for our brightest and most promising young people to stay here rather than migrate to the cities. It has brought good jobs, a better living standard, nicer homes, and development away from our former dependence on

document.text: The Historic Appomattox Station Arts and Crafts Center will have some of its members demonstrating their craft on Saturday, April 10 from 1 to 5 p.m. Demonstrations will be in the third room of the depot and will consist of quilling, bas ketry, quilting, making dough dolls, applehead dolls and bonnets. Several of these craftsmen will also be  demonstrating earlier from 930 a.m. to 1100 a.m. on the concourse of the Appomattox High School where 4-H club members from 19 counties will be holding an Arts  Crafts contest. We invite you to come and observe the craftsmen and also browse through the center.

document.text: The Historic Appomattox Station Arts and Crafts Center is now open Tuesdays through Saturdays 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday 1 p.m. - 5 p.m. The shop will be closed on Mondays except for holiday Mondays when it will be kept open. New hours took effect the first of June and will continue into fall. The center offers a wide variety of locally created arts and crafts. You Will find .many items of interest to yoq or to give as gifts-ceramic - ware, dried floral arrangem ents, beaded jewelry, split oak baskets, toys, dolls, a variety of bonnets and hats, knit and crocheted items etc. . . There are also fine decorator items to grace your home such as quilts, pillow covers, horse hames mirrors, wall hangings, hanging planters, and oil paintings. Any artist or craftsperson in Appomattox County is eligible for membership in H.A.S.A.C. C. If you have a special skill or talent you might consider joining the center and putting your handmade items in the shop to sell. Stop by the Railroad Station on Main St in Appomattox and see for yourself what the Arts and Crafts Center has to Offer. Chances are youll enjoy your visit.

document.text: THE DEAD AT APPOMATTOX. The tablets erected at Appomat tox Court House, by the War Depart ment, to mark prominent spots that figured in the closing scenes of the civil war, are to be increased by yet another, the expense of which, how ever, is to be met by private individu als who are interested in the proposi tion to recognize in an appropriate way the courage and self-sacrifice that Americans have proved them selves capable of in trying times. Before reaching Grants headquar ters, on the way from, Appomattox station, there is a little inclosure be hind a plain fence of boards, nailed horizontally to posts, unpainted, un marked, andmeaniugless to the casual visitor. There were not many casu alties about Appomattox, for there was no set battle, both sides being on the move and indulging principally in skirmish fighting. But there were some deaths, all of which might have been avoided if it could have been known a few hours earlier how complete the Confederates were re duced and surrounded. L After the surrender..some of the dead wère collected and buried in the space proposed to be marked by a tablet similar to those erected by Jhe -government. document.text: the Appomattox River and setting fire to the bridges behind him. The great wooden truss bridge of the South Side RR over the river was known as the High Bridge and was reportedly the second highest span on the North American continent at the time of the Civil War. The wooden portion rested on more than 20 brick piers and was 128 feet above water the entire bridge was about 2,400 feet long. The pursuing federal forced manag ed to extinguish the blaze after it had destroyed about four spans. Firefighters accomplish ed their task while skirmishers were still popping away in the immediate vicinity. Union engi neers accomplished temporary trestle work which carried trains safely across the Appo mattox at slow speeds until permanent repairs were made. The Confederate railroad had not, in fact, been reduced to such extremity as was whis pered at Farmville, but the steam locomotive nevertheless was about to serve the Army of iorthern Virginia for the last .ime. Early on 8 April 8 four additional trainloads of supplies came down the line from Lynchburg at an obscure siding called Appomattox Sta tion they ground to a halt and began to discharge their pre cious friehgt. document.text: The Appomattox Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy met on Thursday, October 14th, at 730 p.m. at Farmers National Bank, Tri angle Plaza Branch. There Were 15 members present. Pledges to the United States Flag and salutes to the Virginia flag and to the Confederate Flag were led by the president, Mrs. H arriet Cunnngham. Ritual read by Mrs. Cunning ham. Prayer by Mrs. Addie Ould. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved and the tresurer gave her report. Our president, Mrs. Cunning ham announced that on November 6th 11th the National Convention will be held at the John Marshall Hotel, Richmond, Va. Two of our members plan to attend. Mrs. Vara Cyrus has been named an honorary member of our chapter. Our chapter entered a float in the pairade on Railroad Day, winning second place and was awarded a trophy. The chapter also sponsored a Bicentennial Dress Contest at the Festival. First place winner was Mrs. Edna Anderson and second place winner was Miss Mamie Cullup. Each winner was awarded a plate represent ing the Battle of Appomattox Station 1865. Mrs. Lucille Ferrell gave an interesting talk using as her topic Confederate Chaplains. On Saturday November 27th at 900 a.m. members will meet for a covered dish lunch to honor our Real Daughters and shut in. Meeting place to be announced. Mrs. Tilden Lee U.D.C. Publicity Chairman

document.text: The annual meeting of the Historic Appomattox Station Arts  Crafts Center, Inc. will take place at 10 a.m., Thurs., Mar. 13, 1975 at Farmers National Bank community room, Triangular Plaza Shop ping Center. The Arts  Crafts Center will begin its second year of operation with a first week of April Grand Opening in the Appomattox Railroad Sta tion, Main Street. As the March 13th meeting is the annual meeting and general election, all old members and prospective new members are encouraged to attend. Major items on the agenda include election of officers and Board members ammendments to the By-Laws and the operation of the station shop for the 1975 season. During the 1974 season, the Arts  Crafts Center member ship numbered more than 60 citizens, mostly residents of Appomattox County. This year, the Center is looking toward an increased member ship, scale of operation, and gross sales, plus an increased tourist trade to Downtown Appomattox. Membership is only 5.00 for individuals, and 7.50 for families, and grants the privilege to consign original. arts  crafts plus historic artifacts and antiques to the station shop for sale. A W ater Control Board stream classification review meeting will be held at Central Virginia Community College in Lynchburg on April, 8,1975 and Councilman Ronnie Spiggle, W . S. Slagle, Town Manager and Mayor Henry Pack plan to represent the Town of Appo mattox at this meeting. The Loudoun County Board of Supervisors is polling most Cities, Counties, and Towns in  the state to determine if there is sufficient interest in the utility electrical rate situation to justify requesting that the Governor call the Legislature back into session after March 15,1975 to speak to the energy and utility cost problem. The Town of Appom attox has received such a questionable and council feels that this matter is of grave concern to the citizens in the town and county and is in favor of voting Y E S, they do feel it is important to ask the Governor to call Legislature back into session to review this situation. Council was informed that the State of Virginia has passed a law to the effect that all jurisdictions must have eros ion and Sedim ent Control Ordinances by July 1, 1975. The Town Council agreed that the town should come underrthe County Ordinance if the County of Appomattox has no objects ion. Historic Appomattox Station Arts and Crafts Center re quested tbst, they be allowed to renew their learn on a portion of the depot for the period April 1, 1975 through Decern her 31, 1975. Council approved the request from the Center with the exception of Railroad Day Weekend that has been planned for the second week end in October. An amendment to the Town Code has been passed to change the meeting date for regular council meetings from the third Monday night of each month to the second Monday night of each month effective immedi ately.

document.text: So he began researching that particular period in history and writing articles for the I armville Herald. At the urging of Mr. J.B . Wall, publisher of the Herald and others, he began assembling the articles and photo graphs for the book. In, writing this volume, which deals with the events of April 6 and 7, 1865,1 have tried to give a detailed account of the movements of the armies those two days, along with descriptions of the battles of Saylers Creek, High Bridge, FarmvUle and Cumberland Church, says Calkins. To help the reader understand these I have included numerous maps and photographs to give- a Visual picture of what really happened those last days.- The story is told from the eyes of the common soldiers and not .the generals, so the average person can see the war as most of the fighting men saw it. Included in the book are footnotes, a bibliography, units engaged, and casualty lists. As the title implies, the story ends 36 hours before the surrender with the armies leaving the Farmville area. Calkins says he is currently working on a sequel to the book which will pick up where he left off and detail the Battles of Appomattox Station, Appomattox Court House, and the days the armies spent in the area after the surrender. The book is published in paperback by the I armville Herald. It consists o f 80 pages. 18 maps and 70 photos and illustrations. It can be purchased at the Appomattox Court House National Historic Park and the Petersburg National Military Park. It is also available through the Lynchburg Civil War Roundtable. document.text: seen later at Appomattox Station. Earlys positon was overwhelmed and Confederate resistance in the Valley ended, clearing the way for Sheridan to destroy the railroads of the Piedmont region at leisure. Charlottesville was occupied on March 3 and there Sheri dans army broke track and bridges on the Orange and Alexandria leading to Lynch burg and the Virginia and Central leading to Gordons- ville. Custer wrecked track and bridges as far south as Amherst Court House, sixteen miles from Lynchburg, a n o t h e r youthful general, Wesley Mer- rit, led a division to the James River Canal to destroy its locks, embankments, and barg es. Sheridans intension was to cross the James River near New Market in order to raid the South Side RR at Farm ville near which stood the vulner able and costly High Bridge ever .the Appomattox. His designs were thwarted, how ever, b ecause Confederated burned the bridges over the James and because the river was too swollen to be crossed on the pontoons he had brought for that purpose. He therefore proceeded to destroy rail and brides north of Richmond. The fall of the capitol was at hand. Out of desperation, the Confederate high command evolved a plan. A surprise attack was to cripple Grants army, making it possible to hold Richmond and Petersburg with a reduced force. Lee was then to move south on the railroad, join Johnston, and crush Sherman. That done, the united Confederate forces could return to defeat Grant. This was purely unrealistic, but it was attempted - and failed. On 25 March, Gordon surprised and stormed Fort Stedman at Contd on pg. 8

document.text: One of the outstanding events in Appomattox in recent years was the coming of Transcontinental Natural Gas Pipe Line Corporation. This big concern has a main line across our county, and one of its big pump sta tions near the Town of Appomattox. Otis P. Dewberry came to Appo mattox with Transco and has served as Superintendent of Compressor Station 17, the Appomattox Station. He quickly won the respect and es teem of townspeople and he has at all times been active in community affairs. The large staff at Transco has worked smoothly under his lead ership. One and all will miss Otis P. Dewberry, now that he is being trans ferred to a similar post in Georgia. When the Transco Company put up a number of homes for some of its Appomattox employees, by common consent, the development was called Dewberry Hill. Let it be continued that way, so Appomattox will have a permanent reminder of this popu lar and personable citizen.

document.text: On Friday, April 28, the Historic Appomattox Station Arts  Crafts Center will reopen the doors of the Main Street Railroad Station at 10 a.Tft.  the shop will remain open its regular hours through out the week end. Items consigned to the shop for sale , will include pocket books, caps  bonnets,quilts, split oak bas kets, crocheted items, cornhusk dolls, stationary, china dolls, wooden toys, etc. Members are encouraged to consign items for sale on Thursday, April 27, between the hours of 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. so a good selection of crafts will be on display at opening Friday. The C rafts C enter is a cooperative project 4 many of the local citizens of Appomat tox. New members are wel come to join and consign handmade items for sale in the shop. Anyone interested in joining may come by the station during the open hours for more information. The shop will be open on Fridays and Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and on I Sundays from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. throughput the month of May. In Jiqpr weekly hours will be observed as well.

document.text: Joe Cusaac, a native of Timmonsville, South Carolina, General Manager of radio station WTTX, Appomattox, since September of 1974 will be leaving at the end of this week to accept a position with WDAR AM  FM in Darlington, South Carolina. Prior to coming to Appomattox station WTTX, Cusaac was associated with WDAR  WCRE in Cheraw, South Carolina. He had previously worked with other stations in Sumter and Charleston, South Carolina and Rockingham, North Carolina. Cusaac says he has really enjoyed living and working in Appomattox and has found some of the BEST people in the world here. Jody Rainwater, shown above with1 Cusaac, who has been with WTTX as a Sales Representative since the station signed on the air in June of 1974, will succeed Cusaac as General Manager.

document.text: honored Susan M. Rosser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Morton Rosser, Jr. of Appomattox, was honored as recipient of the Virgil V. Hinds and Allen B. Stanger Award for excellence in religious studies at Lynch- burg Colleges annual Academic Awards Banquet on April 24, 1981. She was also inducted into Gold Key, the Honor Society of Lynchburg College. Susan will graduate on May 9, 1981. She is a 1977 graduate of Appomattox County High School. AC Center to open The Historic Appomattox Station Arts and Crafts Center will open May 1 for the 1981 season. The center will be open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays during May. Open daily except Wednesdays and Sundays beginning June 1. All -members are urged to bring their items to the shop for consignment on Thursday, April 30 from 1 to 5 p.m. The better our shop is stocked the better our sales will be.

document.text: HISTORIC, EDUCATION-. AL FAMILY FUN - these words capture the feeling of the two day Historic Appomattox Railroad Festival to be held this week end. Festival hours are 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. on Saturday and 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. on Sunday. Free Admission and Parking, with food and drink available on Main Street. BLUE GRASS, COUNTRY WESTERN, and GOSPEL music will be featured on Saturday and Sunday, starting at 1 p.m. both days. A1 Reynolds and the Drifters will start things off on Saturday, to be followed by the New Hope Singers and Rob Honeycutt and the Piedmont Playboys. Banjo and fiddle are always a welcomed sound down at the depot. Sunday music will be courtesy of the Hebron Baptist Church Youth Choir and again the Drifters. These groups deserve appreciation of all for their willingness to play free of charge for the community. And an added salute to the United States Army and the Liberty Youth Singers, who will provide free entertainment on Saturday evening. Dont forget to bring the family and board The Bicentennial Limited at 8 p.m. Saturday, Appomattox County H.S. Auditorium plat form for an evening concert KoI patriotic music sponsored by the countys Bicentennia Com mission. Most of the daytime activity on Saturday and Sunday will be centered in and around the railroad station. The Historic Appomattox Station Arts and Crafts Center members will participate, together with independent craftsm en and artists from Appomattox and points West. Arts and crafts categories will include quilts, dolls stuffed animals, cornhusk dolls, knitted and crocheted items, ceramics, wood, leather, basket weaving, pottery, dec- oupage, jewelry, sketches, and oil paintings. document.text: Handmade quilts are quite special, from the simpliest to the more complicated designs. Mrs. Verna Conner has enjoyed making the Crazy Quilts or Patchwork Quilts since 1971. She uses an all cotton lining and the design is made up of polyester, tacked with embroidery thread. A feather stitch is used around each piece of polyester and leaves the impression of a chicken track. The design is Vernas own with every stitch done by hand. Mrs. Conner has her quilts for sale at the Histone Appomattox Station Arts and Crafts Center at the railroad depot in downtown Appomattox. HASTACC is open Tuesday thru Saturday from 1130 a.m. to 700 p.m. and Sundays 100 p.m. to 500 p.m.
